subject: ASG scaling account for cooldown timestamp & in-progress
commit_message:
ASG scaling account for cooldown timestamp & in-progress

There are cases where it takes a long time to create a new resource as
requested by the scaling operation on an ASG resource, for instance, a
nova server creation followed by a complex SoftwareDeployment. During
this process, additional alarms may come in but failed to be blocked
by the current cooldown checking mechanism because the very first
timestamp has yet to be generated. This is leading to unexpected size
adjustment to the ASG.

This patch augments the existing cooldown checking mechanism with a
scaling-in-progress test so that additional alarms arriving during
the very first scaling operation will be ignored.

subject: pass on @abc.abstractmethods
commit_message:
pass on @abc.abstractmethods

Although a bare docstring is entirely valid grammar, those new to Python find
that pattern baffling, *especially* when other similar methods contain pass
statements. So, for consistency, add a pass statement to otherwise bare
@abc.abstractmethods.

Note that the implementation of an @abc.abstractmethod (in the abstract
base class) can still be called by concrete children, so suddenly
raising a NotImplementedError() instead might be "surprising" to
implementors. A no-op such as "pass" or "return None" is preferable.

subject: Fix a race calling blocking MessageHandlingServer.start()
commit_message:
Fix a race calling blocking MessageHandlingServer.start()

This fixes a race due to the quirkiness of the blocking executor. The
blocking executor does not create a separate thread, but is instead
explicitly executed in the calling thread. Other threads will,
however, continue to interact with it.

In the non-blocking case, the executor will have done certain
initialisation in start() before starting a worker thread and
returning control to the caller. That is, the caller can be sure that
this initialisation has occurred when control is returned. However, in
the blocking case, control is never returned. We currently work round
this by setting self._running to True before executing executor.start,
and by not doing any locking whatsoever in MessageHandlingServer.
However, this current means there is a race whereby executor.stop()
can run before executor.start(). This is fragile and extremely
difficult to reason about robustly, if not currently broken.

The solution is to split the initialisation from the execution in the
blocking case. executor.start() is no longer a blocking operation for
the blocking executor. As for the non-blocking case, executor.start()
returns as soon as initialisation is complete, indicating that it is
safe to subsequently call stop(). Actual execution is done explicitly
via the new execute() method, which blocks.

In doing this, we also make FakeBlockingThread a more complete
implementation of threading.Thread. This fixes a related issue in
that, previously, calling server.wait() on a blocking executor from
another thread would not wait for the completion of the executor. This
has a knock-on effect in test_server's ServerSetupMixin. This mixin
created an endpoint with a stop method which called server.stop().
However, as this is executed by the executor, and also joins the
executor thread, which is now blocking, this results in a deadlock. I
am satisfied that, in general, this is not a sane thing to do.
However, it is useful for these tests. We fix the tests by making the
stop method non-blocking, and do the actual stop and wait calls from
the main thread.

Change-Id: I0d332f74c06c22b44179319432153e15b69f2f45

subject: Add freezegun to global requirements
commit_message:
Add freezegun to global requirements

Source: https://github.com/spulec/freezegun

PyPI: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/freezegun

This allows us to reproduce race conditions by controlling the clock in
third party libraries (such as PyPI/cryptography) which do not depend on
oslo_utils.timeutils (and thus cannot be controlled by timeutils' clock
freezing methods).

It allows you to universally freeze the clock when accessed via:

- datetime.datetime.now()
- datetime.datetime.utcnow()
- datetime.date.today()
- time.time()
- time.localtime()
- time.gmtime()
- time.strftime()

Using, for example, a context manager:

  with freezegun.freeze_time(datetime.datetime.utcnow()):
    pass

Consuming projects
==================

This is a proposed requirement of keystone:

  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/227995/

I also believe it could be used to supplant oslo time_utils
limited implementation of the same behavior.

Is the library actively maintained?
===================================

Yes, the library is actively maintained by a small group of
contributors:

  https://github.com/spulec/freezegun/commits/master

The latest release was August 2015.

Is the library good code?
=========================

The actual library is small, and although mostly undocumented, is well
structured and easy to follow:

  https://github.com/spulec/freezegun/blob/master/freezegun/api.py

The test suite is quite exhaustive and includes plenty of negative
tests, for example:

  https://github.com/spulec/freezegun/blob/master/tests/test_datetimes.py

Is the library python 3 compatible?
===================================

freezegun claims compatibility with at least Python 3.3. It seems to
work in Python 3.4 for the use cases I've tested.

Is the library license compatible?
==================================

freezegun's LICENSE is Apache 2.0:

  https://github.com/spulec/freezegun/blob/master/LICENSE

Is the library already packaged in the distros we target?
=========================================================

freezegun is packaged for Ubuntu:

  http://packages.ubuntu.com/vivid/python-freezegun
  http://packages.ubuntu.com/vivid/python3-freezegun

... and for Fedora:

  https://apps.fedoraproject.org/packages/python-freezegun
  https://apps.fedoraproject.org/packages/python3-freezegun

Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries?
===================================================================

Other than oslo time_util's limited implementation, frozendate is the
other, seemingly less popular and less comprehensive option that I'm
aware of and that's not in openstack/requirements either.

subject: Use openstack/requirements for repeatable builds
commit_message:
Use openstack/requirements for repeatable builds

Add this repo to the openstack-base image, and use the upper-constraints
to install the client packages. Will follow up with dependant patches
for the child images to reduce the risk of breaking everything at once.

--

Background:

Many dependencies in the requirements.txt of OpenStack components have
quite loose version requirements, in many cases they will just specify a
minimum version (e.g. WebOb>=1.2.3).

The result of this is that given a Kolla image for Keystone built today,
another build of the exact same ref of Keystone could be broken
tomorrow, due to it picking up a later unsupported dependency.

The https://github.com/openstack/requirements repo exists to bring some
sanity to this situation. (It also outlines other problems it solves in
it's readme).

This patch has stable/liberty instead of master.

commit_message:
ovs: ovs agent updates the wrong port when using Xen + Neutron
Problem:
When VM is under HVM mode, ovs will create two ports and two interfaces for
a single virtual ethernet interface inside the VM: One is named as tapx.0
which is qemu-emulated NIC, used when no PV drivers installed; The other
one is named as vifx.0 which is the xen network frontend NIC, used when
VM has PV drivers installed. Depending on the PV driver's existing,
either of the two ports/interfaces will be used. But current implement
can NOT process multiple ports/interfaces. If it configures(e.g. set tag)
one interface but the other one is in fact used by ovs; it will have
network problem.

Solution:
 There are two potential solutions:
 1. configure both ports regardless which port will be used by ovs; so
 both have the same configuration.
 2. if there are multiple choices, ovs set the filed of "iface-status" as
active for the one taking effective; and others will be inactive. So the
other solution is to return the active one only. If there is any
switchover happens in later phase, the returned ofport should be changed
as the ofport is uniq for each port. Then treat this port as updated and
then it will configure the new chosen port accordingly.
 As the existing relative functions is implemented basing on the
assumption that only one single port/interface exists for each virtual
interface inside the VM. With the 1st solution, it requires much more
effort to change the existing data structure to hold multiple
ports/interfaces and corresponding it will make things more complicated.
So the 2nd solution has been chosen within this patch set.

Change-Id: I06e5e9123731e01e04c5f7f15ef857703521adc7
Closes-Bug: #1268955

subject: Set --min-tmpfs for overcloud-full build
commit_message:
Set --min-tmpfs for overcloud-full build

I consistently have problems building images on an 8 GB VM with
the undercloud already installed (which is the documented flow).
At 4 or 12 GB it works fine, but 8 seems to fall in a sweet spot
where the tmpfs usage of dib causes OOM problems.  4 GB works
because dib doesn't use tmpfs by default with that little memory,
and 12 GB seems to be sufficient to avoid running out of memory
even with tmpfs.

This changes passes the --min-tmpfs 5 parameter to the image build
for the overcloud-full image (the largest image by far) so it will
not attempt to build in tmpfs if there is less than 12 GB of RAM.
5 instead of 6 because due to rounding 6 would result in tmpfs not
being used on 12 GB VMs either (similar to how it is not used on a
4 GB VM even though the default is 2).

Note that tmpfs by default uses half of total memory, which is why
all of the min-tmpfs numbers are half of the expected memory on the
system.

subject: Split the FIP Namespace delete in L3 agent for DVR
commit_message:
Split the FIP Namespace delete in L3 agent for DVR

Right now we are seeing a race condition in the l3 agent
for DVR routers when a floatingip is deleted and created.

The agent tries to delete the floatingip namespace and
while it tries to delete there is another call to add a
namespace. There is a timing window in between these two
calls where sometimes the call to create a namespace succeeds
but, when tried to execute any commands in the namespace
it fails, since the namespace was deleted concurrently.

Since the fip namespace is associated with an external net
and each node has only one fip namespace for an external net,
we would like to only delete the fip namespace when the
external net is deleted.

The first step is to split the delete functionality into two.
The call to fip_ns.cleanup will only remove the dependency that
the fipnamespace has with the router namespace such as fpr and
rfp veth pairs.

The call to fip_ns.delete will actually delete the
the fip namespace and the fg device.

Partial-Bug: #1501873

subject: WIP: Enable Role-based access control using oslo.policy in Swift
commit_message:
WIP: Enable Role-based access control using oslo.policy in Swift

This patch realizes Role-based access control (RBAC) with Keystone
using oslo.policy library in Swift.

All keystoneauth authorisations logic were translated into json
policy format, to ensure backward compatibly.

Note that deployers need to specify a policy file which is created by
themselves. There is a default policy file which is stored in
/etc/swift/policy.json. The policy file can be a base of their cluster.

How does it work:
* keystoneauth works with a policy file which is specified in
  proxy-server.conf as policy_file.
* If 'reseller_admin_role', 'operator_roles' and 'service_roles' are
  specified in proxy-server.conf, keystoneauth updates the policy
  with the information and works with it.

Notes:
* oslo.policy seems to be not supported HTTP_X_SERVICE_ROLES so
  I created ServiceRoleCheck class but it is better to have it
  in the library. I will get in touch with oslo.policy guys about
  it.
* the method '_get_policy_json_file' in keystoneauth.py will be
  removed because this is only for backward compatibility of the

subject: Fix AttributeError on port_bound for missing ports
commit_message:
Fix AttributeError on port_bound for missing ports

If the port is concurrently deleted, db_get_val returns None, and
that causes the Exception to be raised. However, the exception is just
log noise if the port has been deleted concurrently and it does not
lead to failures.

This can happen if port_update and port_delete operations occur
in short sequence and interleave. To prevent this trace from
occurring, this patch checks that the port is being eliminated and
emits an error trace only if the port is indeed to be expected
amongst the list of ports to be updated.

We do not raise an exception to avoid disrupting the agent sync
process, and leave to the admin the investigation of the issue
(should that be cronic rather than transient).

Under normal circumstances, if the port is expected it should
be there, and if it isn't this should be treated as a bug to be
investigated further.

Closes-bug: #1455320

Change-Id: Ic609af0ef6a09b536c882c58c23167c0a469b155

subject: Support of the Linux socket option SO_REUSEPORT
commit_message:
Support of the Linux socket option SO_REUSEPORT

To reload servers processes, the current behavior is to send a HUP to the
process that will (gently) terminate the server. Then, another server must be
started. It means that during that short interval, no processes are listening
for incoming requests.

Linux, since version 3.9, added a new option for TCP and UDP sockets:
SO_REUSEPORT. Multiple processes can bind to the same port if they
each set the SO_REUSEPORT option.

This feature have two usages. It loadbalances the traffic over
multiple processes, useful when the server is not multithreaded. It
also helps to provide a zero-downtime restart by allowing that, at any time,
there is always at least one process listening for incoming requests.
Zero-downtime restart is the main objective of that patch.

The new behavior is to enable the socket option, when available, for
account|container|object|proxy server. The option is considered available when
the underlying OS is Linux>=3.9.

The new runtime options --finish=<pid> and --terminate=<pid> send,
respectively, the signals SIGHUP and SIGTERM to the pid specified.

To execute a zero-downtime restart, a new server must be started with
the --finish=$PID option, where $PID is the pid of the currently
running process.

Example, for a proxy server:
    /usr/bin/python /usr/bin/swift-proxy-server \
        /etc/swift/proxy-server.conf \
        --finish $(cat /var/run/swift/proxy-server.pid)

The swift-init command is modified to use these options when appropriate.

Change-Id: I3a6cd3635545402203fa8c5de0c43ede81fb7c0e

subject: object-replicator warns when object dirs mismatch with policy settings
commit_message:
object-replicator warns when object dirs mismatch with policy settings

Currently, object-replicator runs only for 'objects-<policy_idx>'
directories whose 'idx' is defined in swift.conf. This means that, for
example, if there are 'objects', 'objects-1' and 'objects-2' directories
in some devices but swift.conf only contains [storage-policy:0] and
[storage-policy:1] sections, object-replicator does not seek 'objects-2'
directory.

However, operators cannot be noticed that replicator does not work for
'objects-2' dir because there is no log output. Therefore, this can cause
delay in detecting config mismatches among swift servers or other
unexpected situations and then, in the worst case, this can cause data
losses.

This patch enables to output logs in the case of the mismatch between
object directory infomation and swift.conf. This mismatch check process
is executed after the completion of replication processes because the
sooner a replicator process starts the better.

Change-Id: Ie005775a626f12b0d0fb339533e63918978a89f2
Related-Bug: 1375438

subject: Cleanup object-replicator handoff/rebalance partition syncing
commit_message:
Cleanup object-replicator handoff/rebalance partition syncing

When removing a partition because of handoff or in response to a
rebalance, remove synced suffixes (and objects) based on the work
performed instead of with rmtree to minimize the impact of a long race
window while syncing the partition to the remote nodes (between the time
when jobs are collected, and the partition is removed).

Since a node which is no longer a primary location does not expect to
receive many updates to the part after a rebalance, this change mainly
effects handoff reversion.  When an object server is accepting writes as
a handoff it's replicator daemon is also trying to remove the partition
from the node after syncing it to the primaries.  If it receives a write
for a new suffix while syncing it will not remove the partition.  If it
is using ssync and receives a write for a different object (hash) while
syncing it will not remove the partition, but an update to a
successfully synced object may still be subject to a race
(clean_suffixes goes object by object, but still uses rmtree without
respect the synced timestamps).

After syncing and removing all suffixes in the partition, the
object-replicator will wait until the subsequent pass to remove the
hashes.pkl, the .lock file, and the otherwise empty partition dir with
rmtree.

Also cleanup the ssync interface for remote check jobs during efficient
cross region replication.

Closes bug #1408061

subject: Better storage server eventlet logging
commit_message:
Better storage server eventlet logging

The eventlet hub can be finicky - she doesn't like it when someone else is in
the spotlight (i.e. blocks).  When she's in a mood like this, sometimes she
won't hand accepted connections to the application as quickly as they're
accepted and you see a request log line from a storage server indicating the
response was "handled quickly" well after the proxy hit a timeout and moved
onto another server.  When this happens it's because the eventlet hub is being
starved by blocking operations in the app, but there's little insight into how
much impact this blocking is effecting the server's response time.

Refactor more common request routing into the base_storage_server.  Add
contextual start time to the WSGI environment captured closer to when the
eventlet.wsgi.server's accept returns a new connection.  Log something closer
to the real transaction time in the storage server logs in addition to the
time the request was "in" our app.

More often that not the logged trans_time will be only nominally longer than
the request_time - but when the eventlet hub is starved because of other
blocking operations it can be notably different.
